title: 107_hr3292
content: The Act titled "Medication Errors Reduction Act of 2001" establishes an informatics systems grant program for hospitals and skilled nursing facilities. The Medication Errors Reduction Act of 2001 establishes a grant program for eligible entities to offset costs related to implementing clinical health informatics systems to improve patient safety and reduce medication errors. The program will terminate on September 30, 2011. The grant program covers costs for purchasing, leasing, and installing computer software and hardware, improving existing systems, acquiring communication capabilities for data access, storage, and exchange, and providing education and training on patient safety information systems to eligible entity staff. Eligible entities include hospitals as defined in the Social Security Act. SEC. 3. MEDICAL INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY ADVISORY BOARD. The Medical Information Technology Advisory Board (MITAB) will be established by the Secretary of Health and Human Services with 17 members including experts in medical information, information technology, medical quality improvement, medical records security, health care providers, researchers, and purchasers. The Medical Information Technology Advisory Board (MITAB) will consist of 17 members, including experts in medical information, information technology, medical quality improvement, medical records security, health care providers, researchers, and purchasers. The MITAB will include members from the National Committee on Vital and Health Statistics, the Medicare Payment Advisory Commission, the National Library of Medicine, the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services, and the Agency for Healthcare Research and Quality. The MITAB will follow the provisions of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, and within 30 months of enactment, submit a report to Congress. The Medical Information Technology Advisory Board (MITAB) will submit a report to Congress on best practices in medical information technology, requirements for health care IT standardization, certification of compliance with MITAB requirements for information exchange among health care providers, and long-term compatibility among information systems. The MITAB will submit reports to Congress every 24 months regarding recommendations, best practices, and results of IT improvements financed under grants to ensure rapid dissemination of healthcare IT best practices. The goals include maximizing positive outcomes in clinical care through decision support and emergency treatment assistance. The patient assessment instrument aims to reduce redundant records, paperwork, and medical errors while promoting best practices of medicine. The MITAB aims to support research in medicine and provide an information technology architecture for future needs. Staff and administration follow provisions from the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, and the MITAB will terminate after submitting its final report. Authorization of appropriations is also included. Authorization of appropriations totaling $2,500,000 in fiscal year 2002, $8,000,000 in fiscal year 2003, and $9,500,000 in fiscal year 2004 is provided for the MITAB. Funding for reports under subsection (c)(2) will come from the administrative budget of the Centers for Medicare & Medicaid Services.
